concept.title: Special Status Release Features
concept.shortdesc: This topic describes special status release features and their support scope. It also provides a list of features in special status release for 4.3.1.

section.title: Feature Release Types
section.p:
There are 3 feature release types, of which 2 have special status:
Technology Preview - see below for the definition, policies, and current features in this special status.
Controlled Availability - see below for the definition, policies, and current features in this special status.
General Availability - fully supported features.

section.title: Upgrade Compatibility and Support Scope
section.p: During the development of a special status feature, additional components may become available to the public for testing. Because special status features are still under development, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) cannot guarantee the stability of such features. As a result, if you are using special status features, you may not be able to seamlessly upgrade to subsequent releases.

Special status features are included in a release to provide early access to features that HPE may support fully in future releases, but HPE cannot guarantee that support will be provided or issues resolved in a future release. Some special status features may only be available for specific hardware architectures.

The customer success team may create bug reports on behalf of support cases filed by subscribed customers. These bug reports will then be forwarded to engineering as proposed for inclusion in a future release.

section.title: Technology Preview Definition
section.p: Technology preview features provide early access to upcoming product innovations, enabling you to test functionality and provide feedback during the development process.

p.b: Customers and users should be aware that technology preview features:

ul.li: are not fully supported under HPE (formerly Eucalyptus Systems, Inc.) subscription level agreements.
are not intended for production use.

section.p: In some cases, this may be applicable to the entire cloud deployment depending on the subsystems affected by the feature in technology preview. As HPE considers making future iterations of technology preview features generally available, we will attempt to resolve any issues that customers experience when using these features.

section.title: Controlled Availability Definition
section.p: A controlled availability release is a conditional release of a product (or products) that does not meet a published standard, or for which HPE is unable to provide support under published policy.

p.b: Customers and users should be aware that controlled availability features:

ul.li: are used to limit the shipment of a product or a release to a set of customers who agree to specific use conditions, which include migrating to a General Availability (GA) release when it is ready.
are generally used to deliver early releases of new products or new features of existing products to satisfy customer commitments.
might not include all time-critical fixes, although some defect repair might be rolled in as necessary.

can be ordered only with proper approval and for a specified length of time. (The approval process and order start/stop time frame are documented prior to the release in the controlled availability agreement.)

section.p: In some cases, this may be applicable to the entire cloud deployment depending on the subsystems affected by the feature in controlled availability. As HPE considers making future iterations of these features generally available, we will attempt to resolve any issues that customers experience when using these features.
